title: Shared Values
description: Discover the values that guide you both and how they shape your relationship.

questions.text: The value that matters most to me in our relationship is...

therapeutic.rationale: Core relationship values reveal what we consider non-negotiable. Honesty-valuers prioritize truth; respect-valuers prioritize dignity; growth-valuers prioritize development; love-valuers prioritize connection. Aligned values predict relationship success.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these values are essential to healthy relationships. Different priorities can coexist when all are present.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared core values create strong foundation and mutual understanding of what matters most.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What value matters most to you in your relationship? Does your partner know this?

questions.text: A value I see us living out together is...
choices: Being honest even when it's hard

therapeutic.rationale: Recognizing lived values strengthens them. Priority-making shows investment; growth-supporting shows encouragement; respect-showing shows dignity; honesty-practicing shows truth. Naming what you do well reinforces it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different observations about your lived values are both true. You may notice different strengths.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared recognition of lived values creates mutual appreciation for what you do well together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What values do you see yourselves living out as a couple? What makes you proud?

questions.text: A value I'd like us to strengthen together is...

therapeutic.rationale: Values we want to strengthen reveal growth areas. Time-seeking shows presence needs; communication-building shows connection needs; patience-growing shows acceptance needs; appreciation-deepening shows gratitude needs. Naming desires enables change.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different growth areas are both valid. You can work on multiple values simultaneously.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared growth priorities create clear direction for strengthening your relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What value would you like to strengthen in your relationship? What would that look like?

questions.text: When our values conflict, I believe we should...
choices: Talk through it until we understand each other
Find a compromise that honors both
Take time to reflect before deciding
Trust that we'll figure it out together

therapeutic.rationale: Value conflict approaches reveal processing styles. Talkers need verbal resolution; compromisers need mutual honoring; reflectors need processing time; trusters need faith in the process. Aligned approaches smooth value conflicts.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conflict approaches require flexibility. The talker and reflector may need to blend their styles.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched conflict approaches create smoother navigation of value differences.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you prefer to handle it when your values conflict? Is that working?

questions.text: I believe shared values in a relationship...
choices: Can be developed and grown together
Matter less than how we handle differences
Provide a foundation while we each stay individuals

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about shared values shape expectations. Essential-believers need alignment; developers see growth; difference-handlers focus on process; foundation-builders balance shared and individual. All are healthy perspectives.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different beliefs about values can coexist. What matters is ongoing conversation about what matters.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared philosophy about values creates aligned expectations for how values fit in your relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What role do shared values play in your relationship? Are you aligned on what matters most?
